awd_titl_txt: Role of Small Proteoglycans in the Structure and Biomechanics of Articular Cartilage
awd_abstract_narration:
Articular cartilage provides key biomechanical functions for joint motion, such as load bearing, energy absorption and lubrication. Osteoarthritis, a chronic disease causing cartilage dysfunction, affects more than 27 million Americans and represents a significant societal burden. To restore cartilage function and alleviate joint pain in osteoarthritis patients, it is necessary to understand the structure and mechanical properties of healthy cartilage as a benchmark. Cartilage is mainly composed of collagen and proteoglycan (protein attached with negatively charged sugar chains). The direct contribution of collagen and the large proteoglycan, aggrecan, to cartilage biomechanics is well understood.  Small proteoglycans do not contribute directly to cartilage biomechanical properties; however, they may regulate the structural assembly of cartilage by interacting with both collagen and aggrecan. Combining novel nanotechnology and gene modification tools, this project aims to determine how the most abundant small proteoglycan in cartilage, decorin, modifies the structure and biomechanics of cartilage. The outcomes will have a broader impact by identifying a new molecular mechanism that governs cartilage structural integrity, which can enable the development of novel strategies for restoring cartilage function and attenuating cartilage degradation in osteoarthritis.  New outreach programs will be established to increase the participation of minority students in STEM education and career paths. Specific outreach activities include workshops for Philadelphia inner city high school teachers and students, as well as the development of science museum exhibition displays.

The cartilage of decorin knockout mice develops substantially reduced aggrecan content and impaired mechanical properties. This project will determine whether decorin governs the structural assembly of aggrecan. We hypothesize that decorin regulates the presence of aggrecan in cartilage through interacting with aggrecan in the extracellular matrix, and through influencing the synthesis of aggrecan by chondrocytes. This hypothesis will be tested at a hierarchy of length scales. First, at the molecular level, adhesion between decorin and aggrecan will be quantified by atomic force microscopy (AFM)-based molecular force spectroscopy. Second, at the cellular level, the synthesis and mechanics of aggrecan by normal and decorin knockout chondrocytes will be evaluated by biochemical assays and AFM single cell nanoindentation. Lastly, at the tissue level, the expression of decorin will be ablated at different phases of post-natal joint growth using our novel inducible decorin-knockout murine model. The resulting changes in cartilage biomechanics, including both elastic and poroviscoelastic properties, will be evaluated by our custom-built nanorheometer. In conclusion, this project will elucidate how the small proteoglycan, decorin, regulates the aggrecan assembly in cartilage, thereby ensuring cartilage structural integrity and proper biomechanical functions

por.por_cntn:
Osteoarthritis (OA) is a chronic degenerative disease that affects millions of Americans, especially the elder population. One hallmark of OA is the irreversible breakdown of articular cartilage, the soft tissue directly responsible for joint load bearing, energy dissipation and lubrication. The development of effective cartilage regeneration and disease intervention strategies is hindered by our incomplete understanding of cartilage extracellular matrix (ECM). The ECM is a composite of type II collagen fibrils and highly negative charged, large proteoglycan, aggrecan. This distinctive ECM endows cartilage with its specialized biomechanical functions. The objective of this project was to determine the role of decorin, a small proteoglycan, in regulating the assembly and biomechanics of cartilage ECM.

With the support of this NSF grant, we discovered a crucial regulatory role of decorin in the assembly and biomechanical functions of cartilage ECM. In genetically modified mice deleted with decorin expression (decorin-null), we found a mild increase in the variability of collagen fibril diameter, but an unexpected, substantial decrease in the amount of aggrecan content. At the tissue level, applying our custom-built, atomic force microscopy-based nanorheometric test, we showed that this reduction of aggrecan leads to marked impairment in the loading bearing and energy dissipation capabilities of decorin-null cartilage. These observations highlighted that decorin plays an indispensable role in the overall integrity and biomechanical function of cartilage ECM. At the cellular level, we extracted cartilage cells, namely chondrocytes, from mouse cartilage and cultured them in hydrogels. We found that loss of decorin does not alter the biosynthesis of aggrecan or collagens by chondrocyte, with or without the stimuli of growth factors. However, in the absence of decorin, a lesser portion of newly synthesized aggrecan is retained in the neo-matrix synthesized by chondrocytes, resulting in more aggrecan released into the culture media. At the molecular level, we re-constituted aggrecan molecules into a 2D biomimetic assembly, and measured their adhesion using molecular force spectroscopy. We found that decorin significantly increases the adhesion between aggrecan and aggrecan molecules, and between aggrecan and type II collagen fibrils. Taken together, this project shows that decorin functions as a "physical linker" that increases the assembly of aggrecan networks in cartilage ECM, and this role is indispensable to the proper functioning of cartilage. This research also has broader impact on OA-related public healthcare, for that the outcomes have established a foundation for developing new cartilage regeneration strategies based on the modulation of decorin activities.

This award has broader impacts in education and outreach. Three Ph.D. candidates and three undergraduate students at Drexel University have been trained while working on this project. In this process, special efforts have been made to recruit and retain students from underrepresented groups in engineering, including women and minorities. The research findings of this project have been incorporated in the curricula at Drexel University and benefit both undergraduate and graduate teaching. This includes the supervising of undergraduate teams for their senior design projects to design new engineering products for biomechanics research as the capstone of their undergraduate education. In addition, the PI has collaborated with the inner city high schools of Philadelphia to provide annual science workshops to increase the students' enthusiasm in a STEM career, and has participated in Drexel's BIOMED Summer Academy to engage high school students in a strategically chosen curriculum activities during summer break. The results from the project have also been broadly disseminated to the academic community and general public through journal publications, meetings, conferences, and social media.
